In 1770, when she was just 14, Marie Antoinette was married to Louis-Auguste, the Dauphin of France, who would later become King Louis XVI. This marriage was part of a political alliance between Austria and France.

In 1774, at the age of 18, Marie Antoinette and her husband ascended to the throne after the death of Louis XV. As the Queen of France, she became the focus of public scrutiny and criticism, especially as France faced an economic crisis and widespread social discontent.

Marie Antoinette was known for her extravagant lifestyle, including her love of fashion, frivolous spending, and lavish parties. She was often referred to as "Madame Deficit" or "Madame Déficit," although these nicknames were mostly unfounded.

During the French Revolution, Marie Antoinette and her husband became symbols of the monarchy's excess and disconnect from the French people. They were stripped of their titles and exiled to the Tuileries Palace, where they ultimately suffered arrest.

On October 16, 1793, Marie Antoinette and Louis XVI were both executed by guillotine, marking the end of the French monarchy. Marie Antoinette's final words are reported to have been, "Pardon me, sir, but I have done nothing wrong."

Today, Marie Antoinette remains a controversial historical figure, romanticized by some and vilified by others. Her life and legacy continue to inspire various forms of art and media, cementing her place in history as a complex and often misunderstood Queen.

In 1793, Marie Antoinette and her family were tried for high treason and crimes against the state. She was convicted and executed by guillotine on October 16, 1793. The marriage was intended to secure an alliance between Austria and France, but the public soon developed a less favorable view of the young queen, who was seen as aloof and extravagant.

Marie Antoinette's reputation as an opulent spender and an unpopular foreigner made her a subject of scorn in France. As the French Revolution unfolded in 1789, Marie Antoinette's status and popularity rapidly declined.
